Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ) Chemical Engineering Program Nucleus of Catalysis COPPE/UFRJ C.P. 68502 Rio de Janeiro CEP 21941-914 Brazil Graphical abstract Natural gas is an attractive feedstock for the synthesis of fuels and chemicals, currently derived from petroleum. The increasing global demand for more environment friendly processes and materials is a motivation to look for natural gas chemical conversion technologies. Carbon dioxide is a gaseous compound, which is also considered to be one of the main contributor to greenhouse effects. Methane tri-reforming is an important way for CO2 utilization aiming at hydrogen and syngas production, without separation of carbon dioxide. One expects that the tri-reforming process decreases the greenhouse gas emission. The main challenges in bringing this reforming technology to practice rest in catalysts development and the understanding of the reaction mechanisms for kinetic modeling and process optimization. What can be done? The main goal of this article is to describe factors to consider in search of catalysts suitable for the reforming of flue gas rich in CO2 and related processes. First, we discussed the relevant metal oxides catalysts and the effect of the supports for methane tri-reforming as well as combined or separated reforming processes for syngas production. Secondly, we described an investigation of two different supported catalysts based on multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) and perovskite-type oxides. Structural changes of the catalysts as observed by different characterizations techniques for both in situ and post-reaction analyses. We showed that the tri-reforming processes are promising, but it is important to find out suitable, stable catalysts. Carbon nanotubes are promising as supports because they are capable of dispersing the metal particles. However, better understanding of the surface reaction, carbon formation mechanisms and the structural modifications are essential to explain these phenomena in further improvement and search of better catalysts. Keywords Tri-reforming STM POM CSDRM Catalysts Perovskite Carbon nanotubes Structure In situ XRD TPReaction Post-reaction characterizations 1 Introduction Energy is one of the most important issues that mankind is going to face in the years to come. The problem was presented in 2003 in a very interesting lecture [1] given by Prof. Richard E. Smalley, "Nanotechnology, Energy and People". He made it clear that we must succeed in the challenge of transforming energy sources, and this is most likely to be achieved through nanotechnology. This challenge still remains to date for researchers and industries to attain a sustainable way of life by evolving how we produce energy and motivate people to do so [2]. Today, the main energy sources worldwide are fossil fuels (oils), followed by coal and natural gas, which represent 31.3%, 28.6% and 21.2% of the total primary energy supply, respectively [3]. The use of natural gas is attractive, not only due to scientific and technology advances, but also by its remarkable low emissions, several application possibilities and vast available reserves [4]. Globally, USA (21.4%), Russian Federation (17.8%) and the Islamic Republic of Iran (5.1%) are the largest producers of natural gas in 2015 [3]. They are also among the countries that possess the vastest reserves of natural gas in the world [4]. The chemical industry uses natural gas extensively: combustion for energy; conversion into synthesis gas for Fischer-Tropsch (GTL) and gases, like ethane, propane, butane and higher chain molecules for chemical feedstock [5]. In fact, natural gas is an attractive replacement feedstock for the synthesis of fuels and chemicals currently derived from petroleum. For decades, scientists have long sought efficient ways, both direct and indirect, to convert methane into longer chain hydrocarbons, oxygenates, hydrogen, aromatic hydrocarbons and other products. More efficient processes could create new ways to produce high value-added products, including the utilization of remotely located hydrocarbon feedstocks, through conversion into more easily transportable and useful fuels and chemical feedstocks, allowing the use of inexpensive feedstocks (e.g., methane and other light hydrocarbons) for end products, often made from higher hydrocarbons [6]. In addition, the increasing global demand for more environmentally friendly processes and materials is a motivation to expand natural gas chemical conversion technologies. Carbon dioxide is a gaseous compound, which is also considered to be one of the main greenhouse gases. According to Świrk et al. [7], the energy sector produces two-third of the total anthropogenic greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in 2014, of which over 80% is CO2. Estimations performed by the European Union showed that CO2 emissions have been increasing every year [7]. The new, offshore oil and natural gas fields will increase the production of oil and natural gas, and there are CO2 in the oil and natural gas from these fields (8–18%). In some particular cases, the associated gas is a CO2 rich gas (79%) [8]. Flue gases from natural gas-fired power plants typically contain: 8%–10% CO2, 18%–20% H2O, 2%–3% O2, and 67%–72% N2. Flue gases from coal-fired boilers primarily contain: 12%–14% CO2, 8%–10% H2O, 3%–5% O2, 72%–77% N2, and traces amounts of NOx, SOx and particulates [9]. There is significant investment in research and development of processes to convert natural gas as the raw material to chemicals with high added value, both in academia and industry. These research efforts led to a number of important processes, such as, oxidative coupling of methane, oxy-chlorination and conversion to ethylene, and production of methanol and other oxygenates. The hydrogen and syngas production appears as a high energy value for electricity generation in fuel cells, and gas to liquid (GTL) fuels, which can be produced from fossil fuels, such as coal and natural gas, nuclear, biomass and other renewable energy sources, like wind, solar and geothermal [9]. The driving force of transforming natural-gas-to-chemicals is the use of low-cost CO2 rich methane sources. However, most of conversion processes of natural gas to chemicals occur at high temperatures, with the formation of carbon, and thus, provoking poor selectivity and decreasing yields. So, we need to develop other processes for purification and conversion of natural gas for useful chemicals [6,9]. Furthermore, these conversion processes are energy demanding. In general, the energy comes from burning some fossil source, or natural gas itself. Indeed, we need cheap and renewable energy sources. The fossil fuel-fired power plants release carbon dioxide in the flue gas. In the tri-reforming process, the CO2 can be used without separation, thus resulting in energy savings [14–20]. Some separation processes could lower the power plant energy output by as much as 20% [20]. Hallmann et al. [10] showed that the syngas produced via tri-reforming can be applied to obtain chemicals (methanol, ammonia, etc.). According to Swirk et al. [7], from the viewpoint of energy saving, the tri-reforming has several advantages, due to the presence/addition of H2O and O2, which would inhibit coke formation, and therefore increase the lifetime and product purity. Another very important feature of tri-reforming is that it is not necessary to handle pure oxygen, producing directly synthesis gas with a desirable H2/CO ratio (e.g. H2/CO = 1.5–2). In practice, the unused oxygen in the flue gas can be used to combust methane to ease the reaction energy demand. One expects that the tri-reforming process decreases the greenhouse gas emission, improving power generation efficiency and co-producing fuels and chemicals [22]. The development of new processes and systems for methane reforming must take into consideration the economic viability of the process and final application of the syngas [9]. It is also important to develop new materials or catalysts for these new systems. The main goal of this article is to discuss the perspectives for new nanostructured materials as catalysts, suitable for the methane reforming and related processes. First, we present a short review of the most relevant and recent research reported for Ni based catalysts in methane tri-reforming. Then we propose specific nanomaterials and discuss structure/surface changes and the consequences caused by varying the reaction parameters. Finally, we offer our perspectives for designing catalysts for the tri-reforming reactions. Emphasis is on work from the authors’ laboratory. 2 General considerations 2.1 Tri-reforming of methane processes Methane tri-reforming is an important method to utilize CO2, producing hydrogen and syngas without separation of carbon dioxide from flue gases emitted from fossil fuel-fired power stations [7]. Methane tri-reforming is a combination of three reactions occurring simultaneously in a single reactor: steam methane reforming (SMR), dry methane reforming (DMR), and partial oxidation of methane (POM) [7–12]. The first two reactions are endothermic, while the POM reaction is exothermic and provides the energy needed for the overall process. Literature about tri-reforming has been first reviewed by Song et al. [12]. Complete reviews for different processes for methane conversion have been published recently by Świrk et al. [7], Ghoneim et al. [9] and many others [22–47,76], including thermodynamics of the process, the possible conversions of methane and carbon dioxide for the tri-reforming and the single processes (SMR, DMR and POM). Table 1 shows the basic reforming reactions for synthesis gas production. Some concomitant parallel reactions of coke formation and removal may occur during tri-reforming process [11–13], which are presented in Table 2 . Methane cracking at high temperatures tends to generate carbon. The reduction of CO to carbon and its reverse reaction of coke oxidation by H2O are temperature dependent, and thermodynamics favors the reverse reaction at lower reaction temperatures [22,23]. It has been shown by simulation that high pressure in the reactor leads to a sharp decrease in conversions of CO2, H2O and CH4, and favors coke formation. Promoted catalysts may be more resistant to coke formation at high temperatures and pressures. The tri-reforming process still has a number of great challenges: an efficient CO2 conversion in the presence of O2 and H2O. Coke deposition and sintering are the major disadvantages of methane tri-reforming, indicating the need to develop new materials as catalysts that are resistant to coke formation and sintering of metal active sites at high temperature, and have long life’s suitable for industrial applications. Finally, the presence of SOx and NOx in the flue gas affects the tri-reforming process in power plants. Remarkable was the first work of Song’s et al. [12] group, showing that the tri-reforming is especially suited for CO2, without prior separation, as in non-conventional (CO2-rich) natural gas, which has already been demonstrated in pilot scale in Korea. However, sintering and coke formation on the catalysts still persist, although great progresses has been achieved. Reddy et al. [21] have reported recently an industrial process for the synthesis gas production. The Fluor’s EFG + process implemented a new strategy for the production of synthesis gas for methanol, installed in Brazil, with a capacity of 90 t/d (99 ST/d) (Fig. 1 ), using natural gas and CO2 extracted from the reformer flue gas. In fact, the flue gas from the SMR process, containing CO2 can be recycled by injecting into the feed to the steam reformer. This reduces the energy, because sufficient carbon dioxide is returned to the process. Indeed, adding the CO2 into the steam reformer feed gas results in a higher ratio of CO to CO2 in the make-up gas. The increased reformer throughput increases the reformer heat duty. Indeed, the industrial process for the tri-reforming is apparently well underway. A schematic process diagram is depicted in Fig. 1. 2.1.1 Available economic assessment The tri-reforming and combined processes of SMR, DMR and POM reaction present advantages and disadvantages, however, it is important to have an available economic assessment of the competitive reforming process. In fact, this analysis is complex because it should involve the whole process. Besides, one needs kinetic parameters of the different reactions occurring and the product distributions, in particular the energy balance which is not so favorable because most of reactions are endothermic. The technical and economic advantages were recently reported by Reddy et al. [21], as described above. Similarly, Brignole et al. [22] simulated a complete economic analysis for the methanol plant. The commercial production of methanol is accomplished by CH4 steam reforming (SMR) to obtain the appropriate mixture of syngas (CO + CO2 + H2). The calculations were made considering the total thermal heat load for the furnace, which is the most relevant parameter. The SMR furnace demands the highest investment. A favorable economic situation regarding operating cost was obtained for lower amounts of CO2 (50%) in the feed. Those authors showed in their simulation that to “obtain positive NPV (net present value) results, the price of H2 should decrease from 4 to 2.4 US$/kg for the optimal methanol production”. In fact, it significantly depends on the syngas production of the reforming process. 2.2 Catalysts Most publications have generally focused on the improvement and optimization aspects of the reforming conditions and catalysts [9,12]. However, no significant progress has been made on the performance of the industrial catalysts and possible future usage of new materials for catalysts in the tri-reforming processes. These processes require efficient catalysts. The required properties of the catalysts may be derived from mechanistic considerations. Generally, the catalysts used for the reforming reactions are categorized into two groups: supported noble metals, and non-noble transition metals. Most investigations have been conducted to discover the most suitable catalyst for the production of syngas using different processes. There is extensive research work on catalysts for steam reforming, catalytic partial oxidation and dry reforming [23–57]. The noble metals-based catalysts are the most active and less prone to deactivation compared to the non-noble metals, which on the other hand are 100–150 times less expensive than noble metals [49]. 2.2.1 Nickel based catalysts Noteworthy is that nickel based catalysts are widely used in industrial applications. These catalysts should be resistant to sintering, thermally stable, resistant to coke formation and possess active sites capable of converting CO2 and CH4 efficiently in the presence of steam and oxygen. They can be produced at low costs and the ingredients are widely available, making the tri-reforming process feasible and economically viable [50,51]. However, the stability of the Ni catalysts is poor due to coke deposition. The strategy that have been exploited to inhibit carbon deposition has been to control the surface properties, such as metal particle size, addition of promoters as inhibitors and different alternative structures. Recent studies are devoted to developing nanosized particles, promoters, nanostructured oxides, different support structures and lastly carbon nanotubes, which may influence the activity, selectivity and mainly the stability of the catalysts in the methane tri-reforming, involving the different reforming processes [9]. However, the main challenges in turning tri-reforming technology feasible persist in catalysts developments for commercial applications and the understanding of the reaction mechanisms for kinetic modeling and process optimization. It is necessary to identify tri-reforming catalyst limitations so that these materials can be improved. Hence, understanding the process and find out some suitable catalysts to overcome these problems is an important challenge. The most important research reported in recent literature concerning Ni based catalysts for tri-reforming (TRM) are shown in Table 3 . These Ni based catalysts are on different supports such as MgO, ZrO2, CeO2-ZrO2 and Mg-CeO2-ZrO2, with or without the addition of promoters, and showed reasonable conversions of CH4 and CO2 [13]. Song´s group was the first to demonstrate different Ni supported catalysts for tri-reforming and showed activity decreasing for different supports in the order: Ni/MgO > Ni/MgO/CeZrO > Ni/CeO2≈ Ni/ZrO2≈ Ni/Al2O3(ICI) > Ni/CeZrO [14]. They used different feed compositions of CH4:H2O:CO2:O2 and temperatures between 700 and 850 °C. The conversion reached a maximum of 87% at 850 °C with a H2/CO ratio of 1.67. However, the most important drawback of these supports is the low surface area. These supports possess weak acid sites, oxygen storage capacity and strong metal support interaction. The influence of supports has been studied extensively for tri-reforming or for combined steam and dry reforming (CSDRM). Danilova et al. [58] studied the combined steam and carbon dioxide reforming of methane to synthesis gas at 750 °C with nickel catalysts supported on a porous nickel ribbon with MgO under layer, and showed this catalyst to be very stable throughout the test period (18 h). The methane conversion was 94% and the synthesis gas yield was 90%. Noteworthy is the work of García-Vargas et al. [59] who studied a novel β-SiC support and the influence of the order of addition of the metal Ni and Mg as promoter on the catalytic activity and stability for tri-reforming. Higher reduction temperatures were needed when Mg was firstly loaded or when both metals, Ni and Mg, were simultaneously loaded, which was attributed to the interactions between Ni and Mg. The Ni-Mg/SiC (1Ni:1Mg) is apparently a good catalyst for tri-reforming, due to its high catalytic activity and stability (low coke formation). The highest conversion reached was 97.9% at 800 °C and very stable after running 25 h with time on stream [59]. Similarly, Majewskiet et al. [63] studied the nickel-silica core@shell catalyst for the methane tri-reforming process. The CH4 conversion rate and H2/CO ratio in the produced syngas were influenced by the feedstock composition. With increasing reaction temperature, the hydrogen yields increased (∼85%) at 750 °C. For the 11%Ni@SiO2 catalyst and different feed compositions of CH4:CO2, the conversions varied significantly, and in particular the coke deposition varied from 5 to 118 mg gcat −1 at 750 °C, as shown in Table 3. The influence of preparation conditions of the Ni-CaO-ZrO2 catalysts on methane tri-reforming plays also an important role and was specifically studied by Lan-jie et al. [60] and Sun et al. [61]. They prepared the catalyst by varying the time of reflux during co-precipitation, at a pH of 10–12, and a calcination temperature of 700 °C. Indeed, the reflux condition (R-48) exhibited the highest stability during 10 h and conversion of CH4 around 66% at 700 °C. Important papers related to the tri-reforming reaction of simulated biogas were reported more recently by Pino et al. [64,65] studying the La-Ce-O-NiO mixed oxide, with different compositions (Ce1-3xLa2xNixO2- δ, x = 0.1; 0.2 and 0.25). They also studied the influence of O2/CH4, CH4/CO2 molar ratios on the reaction at 800 °C and 1 atm. No carbon deposition was detected after 150 h of reaction for the sample with the smallest metal loading (10 wt% Ni), and high equilibrium conversions of CH4 and CO2 were achieved, with performance in decreasing order of Ce0.7La0.2Ni0.1O2- δ> Ce0.4La0.4Ni0.2O2- δ> Ce0.25La0.5Ni0.2O2- δ (Table 3). Nanostructured materials have been studied in reforming processes. Recently Singha et al. [62] synthesized 10–40 nm nano-crystalline Ni–ZrO2 catalyst using a hydrothermal method to produce synthesis gas in the tri-reforming process. They showed that the catalyst was stable for more than 100 h time on stream and achieved high conversions of 95% at 800 °C. The H2/CO ratio (1.9) was almost constant. In summary, Table 3 presents the latest and most significant reports of catalysts and their performance in the tri-reforming of methane reactions, under different conditions, which are the bases for further perspectives of nanostructured materials. Despite these recent advances, coke deposition and sintering continue to be a major challenge for methane tri-reforming, indicating the need as a key research priority to develop new materials that are resistant to carbon formation and sintering. Approaches to improve catalyst life during the reforming reaction include: (1) high dispersion of active metals, (2) high surface area of supports/carriers, (3) high metallic surface area, and (4) supports with high oxygen mobility. Progress has been made. In general, the inert support presents high porosity, high thermal conductivity and mechanical strength. It has been observed that the Ni salt precursor for the preparation of Ni-based catalysts markedly influences the nickel-particles sizes, along with the type of support, which may have different extents of interaction with the metal particles and affect the H2/CO ratio. Strong metal-support interaction inhibits coke formation and slows deactivation rates. Garcia-Vargas et al. showed this effect with the β-silicon support exhibiting high catalytic activity, and with CeO2 supports, without significant deactivation rates [59]. 2.2.2 Mixed oxides and perovskites Mixed metal oxides, particularly perovskites, have been explored as catalysts or catalyst precursors. Perovskite oxides ABO3, where A and B are generally trivalent cations of rare-earth and transition metals, respectively, are attractive because they exhibit high thermal stability over a wide temperature range, as well as high oxygen storage capacity and oxygen ion conductivity [70]. In a perovskite, A is a relatively large cation, which usually belongs to the lanthanide family, and is responsible for conferring structural stability to the catalyst. The cation B is generally a transition metal with smaller size than the cation A and is responsible for the catalytic activity [9,66–80]. For applications in oxidation reactions, the metals in position B are usually cobalt and nickel, due to their high activity [79,80]. If used in the reduced form, the B metal particles can be finely dispersed on the AOx oxide matrix [72–75]. Such transformation is very important under reducing reaction conditions in which the use of perovskites can allow stabilization of small metal particles during the reaction. The literature has reported that the mixed oxides are very active, stable and selective, compared to other supported materials. In fact, due to the higher reducibility and oxygen storage/release capacity, these mixed oxide catalysts promote the continuous removal of carbonaceous deposits from the active sites, which takes place at the metal-support interfacial perimeter [8,73,74]. 2.2.2.1 The La1-xAxBO3 perovskite type - B (Ni,Fe,Cr,Co) The La1-xAxBO3 perovskite type materials can be prepared by different methods, including sol-gel, co-precipitation and Pechini´s method, with various cations A and B for different metal oxides contents. We selected some representative papers to illustrate their performances in different reforming processes, partial oxidation (POM), steam reforming (SRM), dry reforming (DRM) and combined steam and dry reforming (CSDRM) reactions. There is some work relative to the tri-reforming reactions using perovskite structure as reported by Pino´s group and described in Section 2.2.1 and Table 3. Fang et al. [72] studied La1-xSrxFeO3 perovskite-type oxides, (x = 0.1; 0.3; 0.5; 0.9) as oxygen carriers in chemical-looping reforming (CLR) of methane. They suggested that the electronic imbalance caused by the partial substitution of La3+ by Sr2+ is compensated by oxidation of a fraction of Fe3+ to Fe4+ and/or generation of oxygen vacancies in the perovskite lattice. Partial oxidation of methane was evaluated under atmospheric pressure at 800 °C. The highest methane conversion (over 66%) was achieved with x = 0.5. At higher values of x, the methane conversion decreased dramatically. Their multicycle redox reaction results indicated that these perovskite-type oxides can be regenerated readily, which indicates that substituted LaFeO3 is a promising oxygen carrier candidate for CLR of methane. Ma Su Khine et al. [73] studied the partial oxidation of methane over (La0.7A0.3)BO3 (A = Ba, Ca, Mg, Sr; and B = Cr or Fe) perovskite oxides. The oxygen vacancies were regenerated by passing air over the reduced nonstoichiometric perovskites. The Sr and Ca dopants promoted significantly the activity towards the syngas due to the increasing mobility of the lattice oxygen in perovskite oxide structures. Interestingly, the H2 to CO molar ratio on LaMgCrO3, LaSrCrO3, LaMgFeO3, LaBaFeO3 and LaSrFeO3 varied between 2 and 6. Best results were obtained with Ca and Sr doped LaFeO3 oxides. La0.7Ca0.3FeO3 led to 70% CH4 conversion with 10% H2 and 2.5% CO within 50 min, while La0.75Sr0.25FeO3 achieved a 65% CH4 conversion, 10% H2, and 2.8% CO within 50 min. Vella et al. [75] studied the partial oxidation of methane (POM) to syngas in a self-sustained short contact time reactor, using perovskite-based nickel–lanthanum (LaNiO3 with Ni partially substituted by Co and Pt) catalysts. The activity for the partial oxidation of methane was low, mainly due to the high reducibility of the oxide and its transformation into La2O3, metallic Ni, and Ni oxides, leading thus to the formation of poorly active species La(OH)3, La2NiO4 and La2O2CO3. On the other hand, 5% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed high CH4 conversion above 85%, H2 and CO selectivity around 90%. Gómez-Cuaspud et al. [76] synthesized La0.8Sr0.2Fe0.8Cr0.2O3 perovskite using a polymerization chemical route for steam methane reforming, and compared its performance to LaFeO3. The methane conversion of La0.8Sr0.2Fe0.8Cr0.2O3 oxide was very high at 700 °C. Tests for 240 h on stream under isothermal conditions at 700 °C showed a methane conversion of 95% and excellent selectivity to carbon monoxide and hydrogen of 93 and 94%, respectively. Post reaction analyses by TEM, XRD and TPO showed growth of crystallite sizes, and absence of carbon deposition. Wang et al. [77] studied the Ce substitution at the A-site of LaNi0.5Fe0.5O3 perovskite which enhanced the catalytic activity for the dry reforming of methane. The La1-xCexNi0.5Fe0.5O3 mixed-oxide catalyst precursors were synthesized by a sol-gel self-combustion method. Jabour et al. [78] studied the combined steam and dry reforming of methane on highly dispersed Ni on the structured oxide matrix, giving high activities and long-term stabilities at 800 °C. The Nix (x: 5–10 wt%) and Ni5M5 (M:Ca or Mg) catalysts containing mesoporous Al2O3 were prepared by “one-pot” synthesis. The maximum conversion for methane and CO2 were 82 and 80%, respectively, at 800 °C for Ni10Al2O3 after 40 h. However, the Mg (or Ca) enriched catalysts are less active but peculiarly presented high resistance to coking. They observed that carbon formation was not detrimental to catalytic stability due to predominant formation of carbon nanotubes outside the nickel containing alumina grains. The system LaFe1-xCoxO3 (0 < x < 1) prepared by polymerization complex route (PCR) was used for syngas production in the combination of partial oxidation with dry reforming of methane (CH4/O2/CO2 = 4:2:1) [79,80]. Another system involving perovskite cobalt and iron (LaCoxFe1-xO3) LaSrFeCoO6 was studied in the steam methane reforming to produce syngas and hydrogen [81,82]. 2.2.2.2 Nickel aluminate oxides Differently, porous Ni/YSZ cermet (YSZ: yttrium stabilized zirconia) have been studied as anodes for SOFCs for methane reforming, as they do not only meet the mentioned requirements but also have low cost. While Ni serves as an excellent reforming catalyst and electro catalyst, YSZ is added to support the Ni particles and slow the coarsening of the Ni, and provide a thermal expansion coefficient similar to that of zirconia-based electrolytes. Additionally, YSZ also offers a significant ionic contribution to the overall conductivity. The properties of Ni/YSZ anodes are highly dependent on the particle size and the microstructure of the cermet. Microstructural modifications during operation, like agglomeration and sintering of Ni particles, and carbon deposition, due to the internal reforming of hydrocarbons, are the main causes of anode performance degradation. The cermets were tested in steam reforming of methane, and presented good catalytic activity and stability at 900 °C, showing high resistance to coke deposition and sintering of metallic particles [83–91]. Porous Ni/YSZ cermets with 30 wt% NiO synthesized by combustion and precipitation methods presented the smallest mean crystallite size of NiO for the sample prepared by combustion (20–33 nm), showing a higher Ni dispersion in this system. The cermets also presented good catalytic activity and stability at 900 °C in the steam reforming of methane, showing high resistance to coke deposition and to sintering of metallic particles [85–92]. Among the oxide materials, the spinel oxides have been applied in several fields, due to their thermal stability. Nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) is a mixed cation oxide with normal spinel structure, where Al occupies the octahedral sites and Ni occupies the tetrahedral sites. The combustion method has been used to synthesize nanosized materials. This is an easy and fast method, with the advantage of using inexpensive precursors, producing homogeneous nanosized crystallites, and highly reactive materials [93–95]. Kingsley et al. [95] described the preparation of aluminates with various metal nitrates (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) using urea or carbo-hydrazide as fuel. The literature reported different materials using similar methods [96–103]. Ribeiro et al. [104] prepared the NiAlx:1(x = 1; 1.5; 2) materials by combustion synthesis using urea. The stoichiometric composition of the redox mixture was calculated based on the total oxidizing and reducing valences. The stoichiometric ratio of urea to nitrate (U/N) needed to obtain NiAl2O4 powders is 2.2, assuming complete combustion. The catalysts were activated using a mixture of O2/CH4 molar ratio 1:2, and tested for the dry reforming of methane. This activation method enhanced and stabilized markedly the activity, and the catalyst showed excellent stability for more than 40 h, presenting H2/CO ratio and CO2 conversion close to the thermodynamic equilibrium. In our laboratory, we observed the formation of carbon filaments and coke at the surface, and structure and surface properties modifications (Fig. 2 ). Indeed, XRD results showed that the NiAl1:1 catalyst presented almost complete transformation of NiAl2O4 to Ni°. Therefore, the reduction ability can be related to the average crystallite sizes of Ni° [104]. On the other hand, when the NiAl2O4 spinel or NiAl2O4-Al2O3 solid solution were reduced with pure H2 the catalyst deactivated very fast, which was related to the carbon deposition. [105–167]. In short, what we learned about these catalysts is that the mixed oxides and perovskite structure with metallic phases of Ni, Co and Fe or Cr, are excellent catalysts for methane conversion, for all reactions involving in tri-reforming, and for partial oxidation, dry and steam reforming, or auto-thermal reforming of methane. Further improvements can be achieved by adding promoters to the most active metallic phases and supports. These promoters inhibit coke formation, enhances the stability, besides improving the activity and selectivity in these processes. All these studies and many others cited in the references claim that their materials are excellent for the tri-reforming and related processes. These materials had similar catalytic performance, although each one exhibited specific structural, morphological and superficial properties, which indeed justified the excellent performance in those reactions. However, we do not know why and if those catalysts will be efficient in industrial scale, because, with some exceptions, they never had been tested in pilot plant scale. Coke deposition and sintering can be more severe at large scale operations because of less uniform temperature and pressure distributions, and become the major challenges for these catalysts in industrial application. Indeed, the (tri)-reforming reactions are conducted at severe conditions, and there is always the problem of carbon or coke formation. The open question is under what reaction conditions and for what degree of carbon formation can a specific catalyst tolerate without coke formation that blocks the active sites, while improving the catalyst activity and long term stability, by modifying the structure or facilitating the migration of surface metallic phases through carbon during the process. There are significant modifications of the structures, morphologies and surface active sites during the reaction with time on stream (TOS), which depend on the activation process, pretreatment conditions and in particular of the product or side products formed in the reaction. Therefore, the initial conditions of the catalyst, as synthesized and characterized, are not necessarily relevant, and it is very important to investigate the changes observed during the reaction for long-term tests, using modern tools of in-situ characterization that is sensitive to structural and surface modifications. Such information is very valuable for identification of new stable materials for tri-reforming. Carbon filaments are known to be formed during methane tri-reformig. If carbon nanotubes formation is unavoidable why not using directly multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) as support for metallic sites? It is surprising that only recently that studies using carbon nanotubes in methane reforming have appeared. We will discuss this in the next section, however, the scale up problem under realistic conditions still remains but is out of our scope in the present work. 3 Some specific catalytic systems Here, we present investigation of two specific catalytic systems. First, active metal oxides supported in and outside MWCNT and, second, perovskite-type oxides and their structural changes during pretreatments and reforming reaction, and the process of formation and growth of carbon nanotubes and coke, by using different pre and post-reaction analyses for methane reforming. 3.1 Carbon nanotubes for supported catalysts (MWCNT) The carbon nanotubes (CNT) have special properties due to the combination of its dimensionality, structure and topology. Basically the nanotube structure is covalent CC bonds, formed in layers of graphite. The carbon nanotubes meet the nominal sp2 hybridization [168]. The CNT is becoming important in the chemistry and physics of materials, related to nanostructures. Nanostructure such as carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers and carbon spheres have also been proposed for methane reforming. These carbon nanostructures have high surface area, mesoporous structures, rather uniform pore size distribution, and resistance to high temperature [169]. We used multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT, mean diameter of 9.5 nm, Aldrich) functionalized with carboxylic acid. After functionalization, the surface area was 306.2 m²/g (and pore volume of 1.299 cc/g), which is higher than the MWCNTs (150 - 300 m2/g) [170]. In fact, the functionalization process opens the nanotubes, exposing the inner tube leading to a higher specific surface area. Noteworthy is that this functionalized MWCNT decomposes at lower temperatures than the pure nanotube, probably due to the oxygenated groups on the nanotubes walls, which are associated with increased density of defects. In fact, it increases the concentration of these groups at the surface reducing the decomposition of COOH groups at lower temperatures [171]. The diameter of the MWCNT can be used to control the metallic particle sizes consequently the electronic properties of the particles inside the tubes which are of great importance. In general, the results obtained with the application of carbon nanotubes as a support, particularly for metal particles, show that in order to achieve a good dispersion of the metal particles, it is necessary to activate or functionalize the support surface to create anchoring points for the metal particles for better dispersion [172–175]. Several procedures have been proposed to embed metal particles into CNTs, including low-pressure vapor deposition, capillarity wetting [176,177], electrochemical processes and the use of supercritical fluids [178]. There are also reports of producing CNTs with the desired filling material in place during the nanotube growth. A specific method suitable to remove the fill material deposited on the external CNT walls had not been reported until 2009. Tessonier et al. [179] described a general method for depositing metallic nanoparticles, either inside or outside the carbon nanotubes. This method is based on the difference of interface energies of organic and aqueous solutions with the CNT surface. The organic solvent wets better the surface of the nanotubes compared to water and fill the inner part of the nanotubes. The control of the volume of each phase allows filling the carbon nanotubes with the organic phase and covering its outer surface with the aqueous solution. Astinchap et al. [180] presented a new general strategy to synthesize nanocomposites based on MWCNTs by a wet method in which particles of a different metal are located outside the nanotube than those inside. Noteworthy is that these materials present different electronic properties when the active phases are loaded inside or outside CNTs [181]. Bao et al. [176] studied the difference of site position in and outside the CNTs and found that the metal inside CNTs are reduced at lower temperatures than outside, which was attributed to the different electronic properties of the inner and outer surface of the CNTs. Seelam et al. [175] used carbon nanotubes as a support, and different active phases (Co, Ni, Pt and Rh) for the ethanol steam reforming reaction. They showed that the order of activity at high temperature (above 400 °C) for hydrogen production was Co/CNT > Ni/CNT > Ni/Al2O3> Pt/CNT > Rh/CNT. In fact, inner and outer walls of carbon nanotubes provided high dispersion, size control, and electronic modifications, in agreement with the literature [181–183]. Ma et al. [169] loaded nickel nanoparticles inside and outside CNTs and tested them for methane reforming with carbon dioxide. The Ni particles inside CNTs growth along the nanotubes direction with a rod-like morphology. The authors demonstrated that nickel nanoparticles inside CNTs exhibited high activity and stability. However, they observed carbon deposition on the spent Ni/CNTs located inside and outside the CNT, about 9.3% and 20.8% of Ni, respectively. We have prepared two catalysts with different metals, 1 wt%Ni@MWCNT/1 wt%Ni and 7%Ce3%Sr@MWCNT/5%Co, respectively, using multi-walled carbon nanotube with 9.5 nm, as described elsewhere [184]. The first step was the functionalization of the carbon nanotube. The second step consisted in the gradual metal impregnation on the carbon nanotube. Fig. 3 shows TEM images of this sample, where we observed Ni particles in the inner and the outside walls of the carbon nanotube. The average diameter of Ni particles was 5 and 8 nm internal and externally, respectively. Therefore, these results confirm that metallic particles can be filled internally and simultaneously at the external wall of the carbon nanotubes. Functionalization of the CNT sample with nitric acid was important for creating oxygen-containing groups at the surface of the carbon nanotubes. The catalytic performance of M@MWCNT/M (M = Ni, Sr, Ce, Co) was tested for the dry methane reforming for 2 h time-on-stream, at the temperature range of 500–700 °C and atmospheric pressure. The conversions, H2/CO ratio, CO selectivity and H2 yield for different temperatures are shown in Fig. 4 . The conversions were very high at 700 °C, about 80% of methane and 87% of CO2, and ratio H2/CO = 4. According to the literature dry reforming is endothermic [183]. (1) CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2ΔH = 247 kJ/mol In addition to reaction 1, there are other reactions due to the formation of water and CO2: the water gas shift reaction and methane reforming reactions [181]. Our experimental findings showing higher CO2 and CH4 conversions and H2/CO ratios implies that the CO disproportionation reaction and methanation could hardly occur. The presence of oxygen on the surface of CNT, due to the functionalization, favors the oxidation process and, therefore, higher H2 production, which enhances the H2/CO ratio. The initial step in the dry reforming reaction is methane activation, followed by the surface reaction with adsorbed surface CO2 species or surface oxygen atoms. Therefore, the CO2 adsorption at the surface facilitates the reaction with CH4 producing CO and H2 [185–188]. The catalytic tests for methane dry reforming showed that the M@MWCNT/M (M = Ni, Sr, Ce, Co) catalyst presented high conversions and excellent stability at different temperatures, which are comparable to the results with catalysts for tri-reforming reported in the literature (see Table 3). The 7%Ce3%Sr@MWCNT/5%Co catalyst was also evaluated in the tri-reforming of methane at 800 °C using a feed mixture (CH4:CO2:O2:He:H2O = 1:0.5:0.5:1:0.25). Water was added in the feed gas with a HPLC pump, and the gas lines leading to the reactor were heated at 120 °C to avoid condensation. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 58.912 mL.g−1. h−1 The conversions of CH4 and CO2 were 61% and 74%, respectively (Fig. 5 ). We observed yields of 20% ethylene and 16% ethane, which were attributed to the coupling of CH4. Noteworthy is the H2/CO ratio equal 1.0, resulting from the reverse water-gas shift reaction. These results are comparable to those of Garcia-Vargas [59] for the Ni-SiC catalysts under similar feed and reaction conditions at 800 °C, except that the presence of ethane and ethylene in this work was not observed before in the tri-reforming processes. The tri-reforming reaction occurs in the presence of oxygen, which may destroy the MWCNT structures at higher temperatures. Fig. 6 shows the TGA curve of mass loss of the MWCNT with increasing temperature. It shows that above 600 °C the structure is completely destroyed. The Raman spectrum of this catalyst before the reaction displayed in Fig. 7 showed three major peaks. First, the band G at 1580 cm−1 is very weak and represented the presence of graphite. Band D at 1320 cm−1 indicates the filamentous carbon and the disorder of the carbon structure of the MWCNT. Very important are the peak intensities of the Co3O4, the most intense peaks appearing at 480 and 700 cm−1, located on the filamentous carbon structure. Indeed, the nano Co3O4 particles are dispersed on the filamentous carbon or the well-structured MWCNT. Now, how we do explain the that the reaction occurs at elevated temperature when the carbon structure was destroyed? Raman spectrum showed clearly undestroyed and stable cobalt oxide sites structures, which are aleatory located and distributed, probably on undestroyed walls of the CNT. During the reaction, it forms new filamentous carbons on cobalt sites, carrying with them Co3O4 nano particles, that will be discussed in the next section. 3.2 Structural changes of perovskites and the role of CNT growth on the reforming reaction As discussed in the previous two sections, steam reforming, dry reforming and partial oxidation of methane play an important role in the tri-reforming reaction. The principal studies related to tri-reforming showed that coke and sintering are the main problems. Here, we propose properties of materials that may resolve some of these problems. Structure changes occur during the process and facilitate sintering of active sites and formation of carbon or coke, that are unavoidable in any case. We choose perovskite catalysts for discussion which is one of the promising material for tri-reforming. A feature of many mixed oxides with perovskite structure as catalysts is the high mobility of the lattice oxygen. The presence of transition metals with variable oxidation states in these compounds promotes the formation of defects in the lattice. These defects could increase the mobility of lattice oxygen and affect the catalytic activity of perovskite and perovskite-type oxides. The high oxygen mobility in the compounds with a layered perovskite structure is often observed. The oxygen mobility in the LaSrCoO4 lattice was significantly higher than in the LaCoO3 perovskite [189]. In fact, pretreatments of perovskite type materials and reactions affect significantly the structure of these materials during the reforming or partial oxidation reactions, as reported in the literature for different models [190–192]. However, there are few reports on structural and surface modifications during the reactions and their effect on catalyst stability. Literature showed that deactivation occurs mainly due to the coke formation and blocking of the metallic active sites. Some reported formation of carbon filaments (CNFs), different from coke, that may influence the stability. The question is: how do these structural changes occur during pretreatment and reaction, and promote carbon nanotubes formation, and thus influence the activity of these catalysts and their stability? Are these carbon nanotubes necessary or not to improve the activity and stability of the catalyst? If so, why not use directly carbon nanotubes modified with metals as described in the previous section? García-Vargas et al. [59] using β-SiC supported Ni promoted with Mg and Ca found excellent activity for tri-reforming, which was attributed to the occurrence of interactions between Ni and Mg or Ca, resulting in high catalytic activity and stability and low coke formation [58–69]. In fact, the interactions between Ni and Mg or Ca suggested structure modification of the material that prevented coke formation, but certainly not carbon like filaments on metallic Ni, as reported in several papers in the literature. Therefore, first we want to investigate whether structure modification may occur during pretreatments and/or during the reaction. What conditions lead to structure modification that allow or prevent coke or CNT formation at the surface and may affect the metallic phase, influencing the activity or selectivity and mainly the stability of the reaction? Previously we investigated [193] a cobalt based perovskite catalyst for the partial oxidation of methane by means of temperature-programmed reaction. We found that after reduction and use in reaction, there were significant structure modifications of the perovskite structure and consequently formation of carbon nanotubes and coke influencing the partial oxidation reaction. In this study we evaluated three different catalysts: a pure LaCoO3 perovskite, a promoted LaCo0.8Cu0.2O3 perovskite-type oxide, in which Co is the active phase, and LaCoO3 anchored on a high surface area Al2O3 support. The catalysts were prepared by the polymerization complex route, as described elsewhere [193]. 3.2.1 XRD and XAS during in situ reduction with H2 Firstly, we treated these samples by temperature programmed reduction in a 10% H2/He flow while using in situ XRD to verify the influence of temperature on the crystalline structure and the degree of reduction of the metallic phase. Fig. 8 shows the XRD diffractograms during reduction. The catalysts LC (LaCoO3) and LCCu (LaCo0.8Cu0.2O3) were stable to structural modifications up to 300 °C during reduction. At 400 °C, Fig. 8A shows the formation of an intermediate brownmillerite structure La2Co2O5 as proposed by Hansteen et al. [194]. At 650 °C the perovskite structure collapsed completely, and metallic Co°, La2O3 and lanthanum hydrate oxide LaHO were formed, as shown in Fig. 8B. At this final temperature, total reduction degree was achieved after 30 min. Using the Rietveld method, the cell parameters were calculated (Table 4 ), which allows comparing the cell parameters and mean crystallite sizes as a function of temperature. In fact, we observed the presence of intermediate phases which were decomposed, according to the reactions 2 and 3, and in agreement with Huang et al. [196]: (2) LaCoO3 + H2 → 2 LaCoO2.5 + H2O (3) LaCoO2.5 + 2 H2 → 2 Co° + La2O3 + 2 H2O At 400 °C, the major compound was LaCoO2.5, which was transformed to metallic Co° and La2O3 at 650 °C. Therefore, these results confirm that reduction occurred in two steps, with the formation of metallic Co°, coexisting with LaCoO3 or La2Co2O5 in the bulk phase. The LaCo0.8Cu0.2O3 (LCCu) perovskite was also investigated under similar conditions, and results are shown in Fig. 9 A and 9B. There are two marked differences for the LCCu structure under H2 atmosphere: (i) it shows the presence of brownmillerite La2(CoyCux)2O5 structure, just above 300 °C and (ii) it collapses at lower temperature (500 °C) compared to the pure LaCoO3, with the formation Co°/La2O3 and LaHO structures [197]. In addition, the cell parameters in Table 5 calculated using Rietveld refinement show that high temperatures such as 650 °C cause sintering of La2O3 and Co° crystallites when compared with 500 °C, leading to Co crystallites of the order of 11.1 nm. However, no Cu phase was detected, suggesting a high dispersion of metallic Cu. These in situ XRD results showed the presence of different structure phases occurring at different temperatures during reduction and the formation of a Co-Cu alloy. The hypothesis of Co-Cu alloy formation during H2 reduction was investigated in more detail by observing the Cu edge in x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). Fig. 10 shows the reduction EXAFS spectra of LC and LCCu with increasing temperature. As shown, the Co3+ was completely reduced to metallic Co° at 650 °C. Fig. 11 presents the XANES spectra of the materials for similar reduction temperatures. At 500 °C both LC and LCCu material showed spectra of octahedral coordination, which was consistent with the XRD diffractogram of the LC sample. At this temperature the structure is basically that of La2Co2O5 phase, which consists of (octahedral) CoO6 linked to (tetrahedral) CoO4, in agreement with Hansteen et al. [194]. The sample LCCu reduced at 600 °C exhibited a spectrum which is apparently very similar to metallic Co°, when compared to LC spectrum. However, at 650 °C and after 30 min, both spectra are similar to metallic Co° spectrum, suggesting complete reduction of Co oxide for both samples, in good agreement with the in situ XRD results. These results indicate also structural transformation of LCCu at lower temperatures, which is attributed to the presence of Cu in the perovskite structure. Copper oxide reduces at lower temperature than cobalt oxide, suggesting that Cu influences the Co dispersion during the reduction process of Co3+/Co° and Cu2+/Cu°, concomitantly with the collapsing of the perovskite structure. 3.2.2 Temperature programmed reaction of methane steam reforming for the LaCoO3 supported on Al2O3 As previously mentioned, carbon deposition is a major challenge in tri-reforming. Indeed, carbon formation is unavoidable, in particular on all supported Ni or Co and mixed oxides or perovskite materials. The partial oxidation reaction facilitates the combustion of coke or carbon on Ni catalysts during tri-reforming with minimal effects on product yields and high stability for long-term tests. On the other hand, steam reforming is the determining step in tri-reforming and results in significant carbon deposition, due to the absence of oxygen in the feed stream. Therefore, it is useful to understand the formation of carbon nanotubes or coke under tri-reforming condition, in particular on perovskite-type structures which may be promising catalysts for the reaction, as discussed in the previous section. The catalysts used for the production of CNTs are usually transition metals supported on silica [198], and mesoporous silica (MCM-41, MCM 48, SBA-15) [199]. Carbon nanotube growth has been studied by Hoyos-Palacio et al. [195] using CVD on Fe, Ni, Co and also Mo nanoparticles, supported on silica-gel as catalyst. They observed that the number of walls, the morphology and efficiency of the process depend on the catalyst type. Cobalt led to the growing of CNTs with fewer layers, compared to Ni, Fe and Mo. It produced smaller diameter carbon nanotubes. Noteworthy is that we observed intense formation of carbon nanotubes over LaCoO3 during Temperature Programmed Reaction (TPRe) under conditions of methane partial oxidation, with a CH4/O2/He feed stream containing excess methane, as described elsewhere [193]. The results revealed that after two consecutive TPR´s, the perovskite structure of LaCoO3 collapsed to metallic cobalt particles supported on a lanthanum-based matrix, as reported also for other similar catalytic systems [198]. Another catalyst, LaCoO3 anchored on Al2O3 support, 40 wt.% LaCoO3 / Al2O3, (40LC) with high surface area, was also studied with TPRe for steam reforming of methane, using a feed mixture of CH4/H2O/He = 1/1/31. The TPRe was performed in two consecutive steps. First, the catalyst was reduced with hydrogen, cooled to room temperature, then fed with a CH4/H2O/He mixture stream, and heated up to the final set temperature, at 10 °C/min. Afterwards, the reactor was cooled under the feed mixture and the process was repeated [193]. Fig. 12 shows the profiles of the reactants and products. The full lines represent the first TPRe run, showing H2 and CO formation at high temperatures, with significant methane consumption at 900 °C. The H2 formation appeared above 780 °C, increasing pronouncedly in the range between 850 and 900 °C, and reaching high methane conversions (100%) for the LaCoO3 (LC) catalyst. The H2/CO ratio was 3.5. The dashed lines (Fig. 12a) refer to the second TPRe, under the same feed mixture. In this case, methane conversion and products formation, in particular H2, started at 730 °C, about 50 °C lower than observed in the first step. Moreover, the activity of 40 wt.% LaCoO3/Al2O3 (40LC - Fig. 12b) was significantly higher than the LC perovskite, and the syngas products were formed at a much lower temperature (approximately at 600 °C). Blank test of methane steam reforming during the TPRx procedure showed no conversion, confirming the absence of thermal reactions. Therefore, we can conclude that there is a remarkable activation process of the catalyst during the first TPRe cycle. We monitored the structural modifications occurred after each step by XRD. As shown in Fig. 13 , for the 40LC sample, we observed La(OH)3, La(AlO3), Co° and Al2O3. The diffractogram of the LC sample exhibited only metallic Co° and La(OH)3, this last one due to the hydrated La2O3. We also noted the presence of carbon (peak at 2θ = 26.2°, typical of graphite), only after the 2nd TPRe step. The Co° crystallite size as determined by FWHM (full width at half maximum) of the XRD diffraction peak and the graphite or carbon formed on LC and 40LC catalysts are shown in Table 6 . After the 2nd TPRe step the Co crystallite sizes decreased significantly (last column), suggesting dispersion of metallic Co. Probably, small Co particles migrated through the carbon nanotubes. The crystallite sizes of Co° decreased more pronouncedly for the 40LC sample compared to LC, from 115 nm to 54 nm. To confirm this hypothesis, the samples were analyzed by electron microscopy (SEM and TEM), and the images revealed the presence of carbon filaments on the catalyst surface. In addition, TEM images showed high heterogeneity of sizes and forms, prevailing CNT or multiwall layers with defects, tortuosity and different diameters. CNT diameters varied from 20 to 150 nm and encapsulated metallic particles were detected, as shown in Figs. 14 (c,d). These observations show that, in the first step of treatment, the Co oxide was reduced to metallic Co°, thereafter carbon nanotubes grew during the reaction of CH4/H2O/He. In the second step, carbon nanotubes dragged metallic cobalt nanoparticles along as they grew, increasing the dispersion of active metallic Co sites. The 40LC sample is significantly more active than the LaCoO3 perovskite. Thus, we suggest that the catalyst be first activated with the decomposition of CH4 and then used for the reforming reaction using the well dispersed metallic Co particles from the activation. It is important to emphasize that above 300 °C, the alumina surface dehydrates due to condensation of hydroxyl groups (OH), releasing H2O and leaving anionic vacancies and oxygen ions at the surface. Both form weak acid and basic sites. The surface protons and cations move, exchanging positions on the structure, which lead to new defects caused by multiple anionic vacancies (three or more Al3+ cations) in the neighboring positions, which are assigned to strong basic sites. In fact, these defects, present on alumina support, may have contributed to methane decomposition, increasing the formation of carbon filaments. On the other hand, the decomposition may also occur at the cobalt/alumina interface and facilitate the migration of carbon through metallic cobalt particles. In fact, the 40LC catalyst presented higher carbon formation, as carbon nanotubes (CNT) and higher dispersion of cobalt crystallites. The nature of carbon was identified by Raman. The spectra shown in Fig. 15 confirm the XRD results after sequential TPRe steps, indicating the presence of bands D, G and D’, and a ratio IG/ID = 1.61, indicative of the presence of graphite (Table 7 ). However, the shoulder at 1625 cm−1 refers to the band D’ and indicates the presence of MWCNT, as confirmed by TEM analysis. 3.2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic evaluation is very important to confirm the contribution or not of the carbon nanotubes in the steam reforming reaction on the perovskite type oxide catalysts, with and without pretreatment. As described before, we confirmed the formation of carbon nanotubes and metallic Co particles. However, how can the carbon influence the activity, stability or the deactivation? To address this question, we evaluated the 40 wt%LaCoO3/Al2O3 (40LC) catalyst in the steam reforming at 800 °C for 20 h (Fig. 16 ), previously treating the sample by three distinct procedures: (i) mixture of CH4/H2O/He = 1/1/31 in two stages of consecutive temperature programmed reaction; (ii) direct reduction with H2/He at 650 °C/1 h; (iii) absence of pretreatment. After pretreatment (i) with the mixture CH4/H2O/He, we observed high initial conversion (100%) of methane in the steam reforming reaction at 800 °C, close to the equilibrium conversion, as shown in Fig. 16. However, the conversion decreased fast during the first two hours, which can be attributed to coke deposition, and then becomes stable around 40%, for more than 20 h. Noteworthy is that the H2 selectivity remains high, about 75% and stable with time. The CO formation was around 30% and also stable, resulting in a H2/CO ratio of 2.7, in good agreement with the literature. The fast deactivation observed during the first 3 h in steam reforming of methane can be attributed to the methane cracking and the formation of C on the surface. In fact, during this period the H2 selectivity decreased slightly, some of the H2 might be used to reduce cobalt oxide at the surface. Methane crackingCH4 ↔ C + 2H2 In addition, the water added in steam reforming reacts with carbon with the formation of CO and H2. In fact, the results show that CO increased. The Boudouard reaction does not occur under these conditions, since CO is not consumed. Methane crackingCH4 ↔ C + 2H2 Boudouard reaction2CO ↔ C + CO2 Coke oxidation by H2OC + H2O ↔ CO + H2 In pretreatment (ii) the catalyst was pretreated with 10% H2/He at 650 °C and tested for the methane steam reforming at 800 °C. The initial conversion was lower than 20%, however, after 4 h on stream (CH4/H2O/He = 1/1/31; GHSV = 30 000 cm3.gcat −1. h−1), the activity increased, leading to similar conversions as with pretreatment (i) using the reactional mixture, i.e., approximately 40%. Finally, we tested the catalyst without pretreatment and the conversion was very low (< 5%). 3.2.4 Post-reaction analyses by XRD and Raman 3.2.4.1 X-ray diffraction What happened with the catalyst structure after 20 h reaction with time on stream? We analyzed the spent catalyst by XRD (Fig. 17 ) after reaction and different pretreatments: (i) Mixture of CH4/H2O/He = 1/1/31 in two stages, according previous TPR experiments. The diffraction pattern Fig. 17(i) showed severe structural modifications and increased Co crystallite sizes, around 45 nm. We observed also the presence of graphite structure at 2θ = 26.2°, which confirms coke formation. (ii) Direct reduction with H2/He at 650 °C/1 h. The diffraction pattern in Fig. 17(ii) was similar to the previous case and cobalt mean crystallite size was 36 nm. However, the resulting mass increased 34%, suggesting coke formation. (iii) no pretreatment. The XRD diffractogram depicted in Fig. 17(iii) showed that the LaCoO3 perovskite structure was decomposed into La2CoO4, La2O3 and Co3O4 phases. The sample pretreated with the mixture CH4/H2O/He, presented mean width of the peak relative to the graphite phase (Table 8 ) higher than when pretreated with H2, suggesting the formation of smaller MWCNT diameters. The error in these estimates can be large due to the superposition of the peaks for graphite and La2O3 phase. The sample without pretreatment shows only the formation of amorphous carbon. 3.2.4.2 Raman spectra To confirm the presence of carbon nanotubes, we analyzed the samples by Raman spectroscopy after reaction. Spectra exhibited the bands D, G and D’ (Fig. 18 ). The sample 40LC pretreated with reaction mixture led to a high intensity of the ratio between bands G and D, IG/ID = 2.19, as shown in Table 9 . For the sample 40LC pretreated in H2, the spectrum (ii) showed different Raman intensity for bands D, G and D’ (Fig. 18), with IG/ID = 1.22. Here, the lower ratio IG/ID indicates greater amount of graphite, although band D´ was similar, suggesting disorder of the carbon formation. The Raman spectra for the sample 40LC with no pretreatment (Fig. 18(iii)), showed bands between 1140–1420 cm−1, which are assigned to amorphous carbon. 3.2.4.3 SEM and TEM analyses TEM images show significant CNT formation on the sample 40 wt.% LaCoO3/Al2O3 (40LC) after 20 h in the steam reforming reaction (Fig. 19 (a). Fig. 19(b–e) exhibit the cobalt particles inside and outside the CNT walls. Thin CNT were formed over cobalt particles at the surface when pretreated with CH4/H2O/He and dragged through the CNT and became well dispersed. 3.2.5 Influence of temperature We tested the 40 wt.% LaCoO3/Al2O3 (40LC) sample under isothermal conditions for temperatures varying between 550–850 °C, after similar pretreatment procedure with the reactant mixture CH4/H2O/He = 1/1/31 in two steps. Table 10 exhibits conversion and selectivity of H2, CO, CO2 and H2/CO ratio. The results show that CH4 conversion increased with temperature but decreased with time on stream. It is interesting that CH4 conversions at 650 and 750 °C were very stable, however, at 850 °C the conversion declined significantly with time, which indicated deactivation due to coke formation and sintering at high temperature and longer life tests. Noteworthy is that the H2 selectivity was high and stable, the CO selectivity was low but also stable resulting in constant H2/CO ratio in the range 3.2–4.5. The deactivation was likely due to coke deposited on the cobalt active sites. However, the H2/CO ratio was very stable with time and temperature, and results agreed with those of García-Vargas [59] for the tri-reforming of methane. These results show that the activity and phases of the 40 wt% LaCoO3/Al2O3 (40LC) catalyst used in the steam reforming at 800 °C depend significantly on the pretreatment conditions to activate the catalyst. The tests performed after activation using the reaction feed mixture, with increasing temperature (i), or by direct reduction with H2 (ii), showed good performance for the production of syngas, while without any pretreatment the catalyst was practically inactive. This is due to the reduction of the oxide to metallic phase. The metallic phase promotes, first the formation of carbon nanotubes (CNT) and carbon nanofibers (CNF), and then cobalt nanoparticles are dragged from the surface through the nanotubes, staying exposed inside and outside the carbon walls, as visualized by TEM analyses in Fig. 19. However, the sample reduced directly with pure H2 presented lower initial activity, since the reduced cobalt particles are large. The initial conversion was 20% and mostly selective for CO2 formation. Later, by feeding the catalyst with the reaction mixture, the cobalt particles act as clusters for formation and growth of CNT or CNF, dragging of cobalt nanoparticles, which improves the activity and stabilization after 3 h. The deactivation during the first 3 h suggest blocking of active sites, which were covered by amorphous carbon and encapsulated by CNT, and that occurs during the whole catalytic test due to the appearance of new filaments and metallic sites dragged inside the CNT. This dynamic transformation maintains the methane conversion and selectivity for a long life time after pretreatment procedures (i) and (ii). On the other hand, procedure (iii) is ineffective in activating the sample, indicating that metallic cobalt could not be formed to generate CNT or CNF during this procedure. Our findings using pretreatments with programmed temperature are interesting by showing that they probably facilitate the gradual change of the structure and lead to the formation of either CNT or CNF. This hypothesis is supported by Raman results, confirming the graphitization degree, represented by the IG/ID ratio, which is higher for the sample pretreated with the reaction feed mixture, as shown in Table 9. In addition, the FWHM value regarding the graphite phase for the catalyst pretreated with the feed mixture was the largest one, which indicates the formation of MWCNT with smaller diameters compared to the pretreated sample with H2 reduction. The FWHM are apparent due to the superposition of graphite peak and La2O3 phase. The sample without pretreatment deactivated due to formation of amorphous carbon, as suggested by results of Raman spectroscopy. The catalyst when pretreated with the feed mixture CH4/H2O/He formed smaller carbon nanotubes diameters than the non-treated sample, and consequently, presented smaller cobalt particles, as observed through TEM analysis. The spent sample that was activated by the two-step TPRe procedure and used in steam reforming of CH4 at the temperature range of 550–850 °C, as indicated in Table 10, was analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in air coupled to mass spectrometer. Fig. 20 shows that mass loss occurred around 500 °C with the evolution of CO and CO2, which can be attributed to oxidation of carbon. According to Serp et al. [200] the MWCNTs is thermally stable until 650 °C under air flow, while the CNF may be stable up to 900 °C. The total mass loss after the reaction test was 35% at 650 °C. Water releases around 327 °C, corresponding to 2.2 wt.%, and it is attributed to the decomposition of La(OH)3 and La(OH)x(CO3)y, according to Navarro et al. [201]. Galtayries et al. [202] suggested the decomposition of lanthanum species as follows: In fact, Raman spectra of the 40LC sample after pretreatment with steam reforming (CH4/H2O), (Fig. 21 a) shows the bands D, G and D’ and a IG/ID ratio = 1.72, indicating the presence of carbon at the surface. Table 11 shows the XRD parameters as a function of pretreatments that influence the dispersion of metallic Co° on CNT. Table 12 shows Raman results which show prevailing carbon structure defects, or higher intensity of D band after treatment with CH4/H2O. It seems that metallic particles promoted the formation of CNT, which are susceptible to higher disorder or defects in the structure. The LaCoO3 perovskite-type mixed oxide and 40% wt.% LaCoO3/Al2O3 presented a unique phase with highly crystalline structure formation after synthesis. The pretreatments of these materials promoted formation and growth of carbon nanotubes of multi-phase walls when treated with the reaction mixture CH4/H2O/He. The CNT dragged Co nanoparticles through the walls and allowed the formation of high metallic dispersion at the surface. The 40% LaCoO3/Al2O3 catalyst pretreated with the reaction mixture was the most active and stable due to the higher dispersion of the cobalt nanoparticles. Therefore, we have demonstrated that carbon nanotubes and nanofibers form and grow on LaCoO3/Al2O3 under methane steam reforming after consecutive steps of pretreatments with methane/water steam. The Co nanoparticles are dispersed outside and inside the CNT. The higher dispersion increased the activity and influenced the stability for steam reforming. 4 Remarks and outlooks In the first part of this article, we showed that the development of tri-reforming processes is making good progress. They have the potential to resolve the main environmental problems that are originated from new, increased production of oil and natural gas from offshore fields. Combustion of these carbon sources results in the formation of CO2 rich flue gas (79%) from natural gas-fired power plants. Tri-reforming with methane could convert the carbon dioxide to syngas or hydrogen for different applications, in particular for energy. The most crucial point is to identify a suitable catalyst for tri-reforming. The literature has proposed different materials, based on noble metals and mixed oxides, particularly nickel, cobalt and iron metals [203–227]. The challenge is the stability, or in particular, the carbon deposition on active sites and metal sintering. The mixed oxide, promoted or not, demonstrate to be active, stable and less expensive. As discussed, the perovskite-type catalysts seem to be a promising and suitable catalyst for the tri-reforming of methane. As shown, the perovskite-type mixed oxide, supported or not, presented unique phases, with highly crystalline structure formation after synthesis. When pretreated with the reaction mixture or during the reaction itself, severe structural and surface changes occurred, together with formation of coke and growth of multi-phase carbon fibers and MWCNTs. The nanoparticles migrated outside and inside the CNF walls, resulting in higher stability for the reforming reaction. However, there is a crucial disadvantage, because the increasing amount of CNT /CNF during steam reforming may provoke clogging in the reactor and consequently undesirable flow stoppages. On the other hand, these processes involve different intermediate reactions in the steam and dry reforming or partial oxidation, or tri-reforming, besides other undesirable parallel reactions. Therefore, the main issue is to determine under what conditions the carbon is formed and deposited as coke or as filaments on the active sites so as to find conditions to prevent the carbon formation and blocking of active sites. Up to now, the approaches to solve these problems include inserting promoters of different properties, such as, modifying in particular the surface area, the surface acid or basic properties or particle sizes, inhibiting cracking or side reaction over the metallic sites. We have been working with catalysts of the perovskite structure. The advantage of the perovskite structures is that dopants can be inserted into the structure that could inhibit the reactions for coke formation, but not carbon filaments on Ni or Co sites, as reported in the literature. An interesting perspective in the search for new catalytic materials is to determine whether materials such as MWCNT or other supports with high surface areas and weak acid sites can function as supports and nanoparticles that could improve activity and stability. Thus far, the results show that carbon deposition is unavoidable as coke and/or filaments even on mixed oxides and perovskite like structures. However, it is interesting to note that structure modifications that occur during reaction or pretreatment that favored preferentially formation of multiwall carbon nanotubes during the reforming reaction, in contrast to coke, positively affect the activity and the stability. Therefore, carbon nanotubes are promising and suitable for this reaction. Unfortunately, the surface reaction mechanism is unknown, which is essential for explaining the role of the catalyst on the stability and selectivity of syngas production. Another unknown factor is the mechanism of carbon and coke formation or inhibition, which is the key problem for explaining the efficiency of any catalyst for the tri-reforming reaction of methane. Therefore, we need to investigate the surface reaction mechanisms, the structure modifications and the dynamics of the surface reaction that may affect the surface active sites, employing “operando" characterizations in further and more extensive research studies. 5 Conclusions In this work we present the performance of Nickel based catalyst on different promoted or un-promoted supports, and the perspectives of different metallic mixed oxide and activated multi-wall carbon nanotubes as catalysts for the tri-reforming of methane. We conclude that these materials are suitable for the tri-reforming, exhibiting excellent activity, high selectivity and stability. However, there are significant structural modifications, like sintering, and unavoidable carbon formation, such as coke, and growth of multiwall carbon nanotubes at the metallic surface, as observed by in situ XRD and HRTEM and Raman post- reaction analyses, affecting the activity and stability. As new material we proposed the multiwall carbon nanotubes as support and anchored metal oxides in and outside CNT walls, which exhibited high activity and stability in the tri- or dry reforming processes. This behavior is not sufficiently explored since the CNT are unstable at higher temperatures. Finally, we observed for the perovskites and mixed oxides structural modifications, carbon fibers formation on active metal oxide and aleatory growth at the surfaces during the reaction, dragging the active metal oxide at the surface. On the other hand, elucidation of the dynamic reaction at the surface, the reaction mechanisms and structural modifications aiming to explain these phenomena is the outlook for further research. Uchiyama Nano Lett. 8 7 2008 2082 2086 MARTIN SCHMAL is professor since 1970, became Full Professor in 1985 and Emeritus since 2008 at the Chemical Engineering Department of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro and professor at the University of São Paulo since 2014 – He graduated Chemical Engineering at the Engineering Faculty of the Catholic University of S. Paulo(1964), Master Science degree - 1966 at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro/COPPE, Brazil, Doktor Ingenieur degree (Dr.Ing.) at the Technische Universität Berlin, Germany (1970). He specialized at the Institut du Recherche sur la Catalyse (1981), Lyon, France and University of Karlsruhe, 1983, Germany. Member of the Brazilian Academy of Science, elected in 1999 and of the International Catalysis Society since 2000. Awards : Humboldt Research Award – 2002 – Humboldt Foundation – Germany, Prize from the México Science and tecnology (2002); Senior Researcher award from the Ibero American society (2010); the SCOPUS AWARD- Elsevier-CAPES (2009) and finally the Distinguished Professor AWARD at Coppe- Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (2013). He more than 2820 publications in international journals;250 papers presented and published in Annals in International Congresses, Symposia’s and Meetings. Books: Chemical Reaction Engineering,CRC Press, 2,014,700 pages -ISBN978-0-415-69538-1; Heterogeneous Catalysis and its Industrial Applications SPRINGER,2016- ISBN 978-3-319-09249-2 See publication list (http://www.capes.gov.br/lattes). Founder and President of the Brazilian Catalysis Society -1998-2004. External collaborations: H.J.Freund (Max Planck Berlin), E.Lombardo (Argentina), Schlogl and Behrens (Max Planck – Berlin(Germany), Albert Vannice –Pennstate (USA), Ted Oyama – Virginia Tec (USA)

coredata.dc:description: Natural gas is an attractive feedstock for the synthesis of fuels and chemicals, currently derived from petroleum. The increasing global demand for more environment friendly processes and materials is a motivation to look for natural gas chemical conversion technologies. Carbon dioxide is a gaseous compound, which is also considered to be one of the main contributor to greenhouse effects. Methane tri-reforming is an important way for CO2 utilization aiming at hydrogen and syngas production, without separation of carbon dioxide. One expects that the tri-reforming process decreases the greenhouse gas emission. The main challenges in bringing this reforming technology to practice rest in catalysts development and the understanding of the reaction mechanisms for kinetic modeling and process optimization. What can be done? The main goal of this article is to describe factors to consider in search of catalysts suitable for the reforming of flue gas rich in CO2 and related processes. First, we discussed the relevant metal oxides catalysts and the effect of the supports for methane tri-reforming as well as combined or separated reforming processes for syngas production. Secondly, we described an investigation of two different supported catalysts based on multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) and perovskite-type oxides. Structural changes of the catalysts as observed by different characterizations techniques for both in situ and post-reaction analyses. We showed that the tri-reforming processes are promising, but it is important to find out suitable, stable catalysts. Carbon nanotubes are promising as supports because they are capable of dispersing the metal particles. However, better understanding of the surface reaction, carbon formation mechanisms and the structural modifications are essential to explain these phenomena in further improvement and search of better catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Perspective of catalysts for (Tri) reforming of natural gas and flue gas rich in CO2
